isis.stitle: STEERING COLUMN ASSEMBLY, TILT/TELESCOPING - ProStar - REMOVE AND INSTALL PROCEDURES - STEERING COLUMN

warning.para: The tilt/telescope steering column is replaced as a unit. Do not attempt to disassemble or modify this unit. The tilt/telescope steering column unit is under spring tension and serious injury may result if disassembly is attempted.

step1.para: Remove the horn pad by placing both hands on top of the horn pad and using your fingertips underneath the top leading edge of the horn pad to gently pull upward toward you ( Figure 2, Items 1 and 2).
Disconnect wire connector from the back of the horn pad ( Figure 2, Item 2).
Place a reference mark on the steering column shaft and steering wheel to aid in the alignment of the steering wheel during installation procedures ( Figure 3, Item 3).
Disconnect the steering wheel harness connector ( Figure 3, Item 4).
Remove the retaining nut from the steering wheel and steering column ( Figure 3, Items 1 and 2).
Attach the appropriate steering wheel puller to the steering wheel. Apply enough pressure with the puller to loosen the steering wheel from the steering column ( Figure 4, Items 1 and 2).
Remove the steering wheel from the steering column ( Figure 4, Items 1 and 3).
Remove five screws from the top steering column outer cover ( Figure 6, Items 1 and 3).
Remove the top steering column outer cover and the top steering column inner cover ( Figure 6, Items 1 and 2).
Disconnect the wire connector from the clock spring ( Figure 7, Items 1 and 4).
Verify that the wheels are straight, then tape the top cover of the clock spring to the bottom housing of the clock spring.
Remove three machine screws from the clock spring ( Figure 7, Items 1 and 2).
Remove the clock spring from the steering column ( Figure 7, Items 1 and 3).
Remove two machine screws and the turn signal switch housing.
Disconnect the wire connector from the turn signal switch housing.

calloutgroup.callout1: 3. TRAILER HAND BRAKE VALVE MOUNT PLATE

step1.para: Remove two mount screws from the trailer hand brake valve mount plate and the steering column.
Remove four screws and the left side kick panel.
Remove 10 screws and the left lower kick panel.
Remove two screws and the bottom steering column outer cover.
Remove the snap rivet from each side of bottom steering column inner cover.
Slide the steering column bellow up and off of the steering column.

note.para: Applying a light coat of penetrating oil to the intermediate shaft universal joint and the steering column splines will break up the rust and aid in removal of the intermediate shaft.

step1.para: Remove the pinch bolt from the intermediate shaft universal joint.
Disconnect the intermediate steering shaft from the steering column.

figure.caption: Figure 14. Lower Steering Column Mount Cup

step1.para: Remove four mount nuts from the lower steering column mount cup at the dash panel.
Remove two side mount bolts from each side support bracket and the steering column.
Remove two center mount bolts and washers from the steering column and cross-cab beam.
Disconnect the bottom steering column inner cover from the steering column.
If the vehicle is equipped with a steering angle sensor, disconnect the steering angle sensor electrical connector from the back side of the steering column.
Disconnect wiring clips and reposition wiring harness away from steering column.
Position the trailer hand brake valve, with the air lines connected, away from the steering column.
Remove the steering column.
Position the steering column.

note.para: Be sure to route the electrical harness and the air harness between the steering column shaft and the steering column inner cover.

step1.para: Connect the bottom steering column inner cover to the steering column ( Figure 16, Items 2 and 5).
Install two side mount bolts on each side support bracket and the steering column ( Figure 15, Items 1, 3, and 4). Torque bolts to 14 to 17 lbf-ft (19 to 23 N•m).
Install four mount nuts on the lower steering column mount cup at the dash panel ( Figure 14, Items 1, 3, and 4. Torque nuts to 17 to 20 lbf-ft (26 to 27 N•m).
Secure the steering column to the cross-cab beam with two center mount bolts and washers ( Figure 15, Items 2, 3, and 5). Torque bolts to 20 to 25 lbf-ft (27 to 34 N•m).
Route wiring harness back onto steering column and secure wire clips.
If the vehicle is equipped with a steering angle sensor, connect the steering angle sensor electrical connector on the back side of the steering column ( Figure 16, Items 3 and 5).
Secure the bottom steering column inner cover to the steering column with one snap rivet on each side ( Figure 12, Items 5 and 6).
Connect the intermediate shaft universal joint to the steering column ( Figure 13, Items 1 and 3).
Install the pinch bolt on the intermediate shaft universal joint ( Figure 13, Items 1 and 2). Torque bolt to 50 to 60 lbf-ft (68 to 81 N•m).

note.para: Prior to installing the steering column bellow on the steering column, ensure that the first bellow and last bellow contain the plastic rings for mounting the steering column bellow. The electrical harness and air harness must be routed through the bellow during installation.

step1.para: Slide the steering column bellow onto the steering column ( Figure 12, Items 1 and 2).

note.para: Ensure that the last bellow and plastic ring of the steering column bellow are captured into the bottom steering column outer cover and bottom steering column inner cover properly during installation.

step1.para: Install the bottom steering column outer cover and secure with two screws ( Figure 12, Items 3 and 4). Torque bolts to 10 to 25 lbf-in (1.1 to 2.8 N•m).
Install the left, lower kick panel and secure with 10 screws ( Figure 11, Items 2 and 3).
Install the left, side kick panel and secure with four screws ( Figure 11, Items 1 and 2).
Install the trailer hand brake valve mount plate on the steering column and secure with two mount screws ( Figure 10, Items 1, 2, and 3). Torque screws to 35 to 45 lbf-in (4 to 5 N•m).
Connect the wire connector to the turn signal switch housing ( Figure 9, Items 2 and 4).
Align the turn signal switch housing alignment tab on the steering column ( Figure 9, Items 3 and 5).
Secure the turn signal switch housing on the steering column with two machine screws ( Figure 9, Items 1, 2, and 3). Torque machine screws to 10 to 25 lbf-in (1.1 to 2.8 N•m).

caution.para: Read and follow directions for the clock spring installation very carefully. This device will break if not properly installed.

item.para: If the clock spring binds or the tape that was installed during the removal procedures is broken, perform step 1.
If the clock spring is secured with tape, skip step 1.

step1.para: To ensure that the spring is centered, do the following:

item.para: Turn the clock spring cover counterclockwise until it is locked.
Turn the clock spring cover clockwise 4.5 turns.
Align the arrows on the clock spring cover and mounting body (Figure 8, item 3)
Tape the top cover of the clock spring to the bottom housing of the clock spring.

step1.para: Install the clock spring onto the steering column and secure the clock spring with three machine screws ( Figure 7, Items 1, 2, and 3). Torque machine screws to 10 to 25 lbf-in (1.1 to 2.8 N•m).
Connect the wire connector to the clock spring ( Figure 7, Items 1 and 4).

note.para: There are four standard screws and one machine screw used for mounting the top steering column outer cover. Be sure to install the machine screw into the top mounting hole, as this position secures the top steering column outer cover to the steering column.

step1.para: Install the top steering column outer cover and top steering column inner cover ( Figure 6, Items 1 and 2). The top steering column covers must capture the top bellow and plastic ring of the steering column bellow.
Secure the top steering column outer cover to the top steering column inner cover with five screws ( Figure 6, Items 1, 2, and 3). Torque screws to 10 to 25 lbf-in (1.1 to 2.8 N•m).

caution.para: Make sure the clip on the top of the clock spring properly aligns with the slot in the steering wheel and that the clock spring wiring is fed through the appropriate hole in the steering wheel. The clock spring could be damaged if these components are not aligned properly during installation.

note.para: If a new steering wheel is being installed, place the new steering wheel next to the removed steering wheel and copy the reference mark that was made during the removal procedures onto the new steering wheel.

step1.para: Position the steering wheel on the steering column shaft, making sure to align the marks that were made during the removal procedures ( Figure 3, Item 3).
Install the retaining nut on the steering wheel and steering column ( Figure 3, Items 1 and 2). Torque nut to 60 to 65 lbf-ft (81 to 88 N•m).
Connect the steering wheel harness connector ( Figure 3, Item 4).
Connect the wire connector on the back of the horn pad ( Figure 2, Item 2).

caution.para: Do not attempt to snap all four horn pad retaining posts in at the same time by hitting the steering wheel in the center, otherwise damage may result.

step1.para: Lay the horn pad on top of the steering wheel and align the four horn pad retaining posts directly on top of their respective mating holes. Using the palm of your hand, gently tap each of the four corners of the horn pad starting with the lower right, then lower left, then upper right, and finishing with the upper left ( Figure 2, Items 1 and 2).
